message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the information given, the child is likely around 8-10 months old. At this age, pulling up to stand is a common developmental milestone, whereas pointing to body parts, saying clear words, and turning pages in a book typically occur later on in development.

We refer to the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines on developmental milestones for help. Based on the patient's age and current skills/behaviors, the next expected milestone would be to pull up to stand, making option (A) the correct answer. Points to 3 body parts and turns pages in a book are expected at 12-15 months, while saying at least 1 word clearly is expected at 9-12 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on child development for help. Based on the provided information, the child is likely between 7-9 months old. At this age, pulling up to stand is expected, while pointing to body parts, saying at least one word clearly, and turning pages in a book typically occur later in development. Therefore, (A) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to developmental milestones, pulling up to stand is expected at 9-10 months old. The other options are expected at later ages - pointing to body parts at 15-18 months, saying at least 1 word clearly at 12 months, and turning pages in a book at 18-24 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to typical milestones of infant development, pulling up to stand is expected at around 9-10 months of age, which is the next developmental stage after crawling. The other options are expected at different ages, with pointing to body parts and saying at least 1 word clearly expected around 12 months and turning pages in a book around 18 months.

At this developmental age, a typical healthy child should be able to pull up to stand (option A). Points to body parts (option B) and says at least 1 word clearly (option C) typically occur around 12 months of age. Turning pages in a book (option D) typically occurs around 18 months of age.

The child’s development is consistent with a 9-10 month old infant, and among the options, pulling up to stand is an expected developmental milestone for this age range. Pointing to body parts, saying at least 1 word clearly, and turning pages in a book are expected for 12-15 month old infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The child’s age and current skills put her in the 7-10 month age range. At this stage, a healthy child is expected to be able to pull up to stand (option A). Pointing to body parts (option B) usually begins at around 10-12 months. Saying at least 1 clear word (option C) typically occurs between 11-14 months. Turning pages in a book (option D) usually develops around 10-12 months as well, but is not as important a milestone as pulling up to stand.

We refer to developmental milestone charts for help. At this age (around 8-9 months), a healthy infant is expected to be able to pull up to stand while holding onto furniture or other support. Points to body parts, saying words clearly, and turning pages in a book are skills expected at later developmental stages (around 12-15 months). The pincer grasp, looking for dropped objects, and saying "mama and dada" are appropriate for this developmental age.
